title: Psalms Chapter 73 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 73 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 73 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 73.

questions.question: According to Psalms 73:1, to whom is God good?
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:1 states, 'Truly God is good to Israel, even to such as are of a clean heart.'

questions.question: In Psalms 73:3, what emotion did the psalmist feel when he saw the prosperity of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Envy
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:3 says, 'For I was envious at the foolish, when I saw the prosperity of the wicked.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 73:5, how are the wicked different from other men?
questions.correctAnswer: They are not in trouble
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:5 states, 'They are not in trouble as other men; neither are they plagued like other men.'

questions.question: What covers the wicked as a garment according to Psalms 73:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Violence
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:6 says, '...violence covereth them as a garment.'

questions.question: Psalms 73:7 describes the eyes of the wicked as standing out with what?
questions.correctAnswer: Fatness
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:7 states, 'Their eyes stand out with fatness.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 73:9, where does the tongue of the wicked walk?
questions.correctAnswer: Through the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:9 says, '...and their tongue walketh through the earth.'

questions.question: What question do the people ask in Psalms 73:11?
questions.correctAnswer: How doth God know?
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:11 states, 'And they say, How doth God know? and is there knowledge in the most High?'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 73:13 says the psalmist believed he had cleansed his heart in vain.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:13 says, 'Verily I have cleansed my heart in vain.'

questions.question: What did the psalmist do in Psalms 73:17 to understand the end of the wicked?
options: Went into the sanctuary of God
questions.correctAnswer: Went into the sanctuary of God
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:17 states, 'Until I went into the sanctuary of God; then understood I their end.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 73:20, what happens to the wicked when the Lord awakens?
questions.correctAnswer: He shall despise their image
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:20 says, '...when thou awakest, thou shalt despise their image.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 73:25: 'Whom have I in heaven but ___?'
questions.correctAnswer: thee
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:25 states, 'Whom have I in heaven but thee?'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 73:26 says that the psalmist's flesh and heart do not fail.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:26 states, 'My flesh and my heart faileth,' indicating they do fail.

questions.question: According to Psalms 73:28, why is it good for the psalmist to draw near to God?
questions.correctAnswer: To declare all God's works
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:28 says, 'I have put my trust in the Lord GOD, that I may declare all thy works.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 73:22 describes the psalmist as wise and understanding.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:22 states, 'So foolish was I, and ignorant,' which is the opposite of wise and understanding.

questions.question: According to Psalms 73:23, how does the psalmist describe God's presence with him?
options: Continually with me, holding me by my right hand
questions.correctAnswer: Continually with me, holding me by my right hand
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:23 says, 'Nevertheless I am continually with thee: thou hast holden me by my right hand.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 73 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 73 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is envious of the prosperity of the wicked and feels discouraged. Based on Psalms 73, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in such times?
options: God is good to those with a clean heart and will reveal the end of the wicked.
The wicked will always prosper and be stronger than the righteous.
Envy is a sign of true faith and should be embraced.
One should give up trusting God when the wicked seem successful.
questions.correctAnswer: God is good to those with a clean heart and will reveal the end of the wicked.
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:1 teaches God’s goodness to the pure in heart; verses 16-17 show understanding comes in the sanctuary revealing the fate of the wicked; verses 18-20 describe their downfall. This encourages trust despite outward appearances.

questions.question: How does Psalms 73 instruct believers to respond when they feel their faith and innocence are questioned because the wicked prosper?
options: Recognize that God chastens us but also guides us to glory.
Stop seeking God and follow the ways of the wicked.
Ignore the question and focus on worldly gain.
Assume that God does not care about justice.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that God chastens us but also guides us to glory.
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 express feeling plagued despite innocence; verses 23-24 affirm God’s continual presence and guidance leading to glory, encouraging perseverance and trust in God’s discipline.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with pride and arrogance due to material success. According to Psalms 73, what lesson about pride and its consequences can be shared?
options: Pride surrounds the wicked like a chain and leads to destruction.
Pride is a necessary trait for success and honor.
Material success is the ultimate sign of God’s blessing.
Arrogance will protect one from hardship.
questions.correctAnswer: Pride surrounds the wicked like a chain and leads to destruction.
questions.explanation: Verse 6 describes pride compassing the wicked like a chain; verses 18-19 explain God sets them in slippery places leading to destruction, warning against pride and arrogance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 73 encourage believers to find strength when their flesh and heart fail?
options: God is the strength of the heart and a lasting portion.
Rely on personal strength and worldly resources.
Ignore the weakness and pretend to be strong.
Seek only human comfort and advice.
questions.correctAnswer: God is the strength of the heart and a lasting portion.
questions.explanation: Verse 26 clearly states that when flesh and heart fail, God is the strength and eternal portion, teaching believers to depend on God’s sustaining power.

questions.question: What does Psalms 73 teach about humility and self-awareness in the presence of God?
options: The psalmist admits being foolish and ignorant, like a beast before God.
Believers should boast about their wisdom and strength.
Self-awareness is not important for faith.
Humility means not trusting God’s guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: The psalmist admits being foolish and ignorant, like a beast before God.
questions.explanation: Verse 22 shows the psalmist’s humility and recognition of ignorance before God, encouraging believers to approach God with humility and openness to learning.

questions.question: A Christian is confused about how God governs justice because they see the wicked prospering. According to Psalms 73, what insight can you share about God’s justice?
options: God will ultimately bring the wicked to sudden destruction.
God does not notice the wicked’s actions.
The wicked’s prosperity is permanent and rewarded by God.
God’s justice is delayed and uncertain.
questions.correctAnswer: God will ultimately bring the wicked to sudden destruction.
questions.explanation: Verses 18-20 describe how God sets the wicked in slippery places and casts them down into destruction swiftly, affirming that God’s justice is sure and decisive.

questions.question: How does Psalms 73 illustrate the importance of personal devotion and seeking God’s presence during spiritual confusion?
options: Going into the sanctuary of God led to understanding the fate of the wicked.
Avoiding church and personal devotion increases understanding.
Seeking God’s presence is unnecessary for clarity.
questions.correctAnswer: Going into the sanctuary of God led to understanding the fate of the wicked.
questions.explanation: Verse 17 shows the psalmist gained insight when entering God’s sanctuary, teaching the value of devotional worship and fellowship for spiritual clarity.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 73, the psalmist felt grieved and pricked in his heart because he envied the wicked’s prosperity.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 21 states that the psalmist’s heart was grieved and pricked in his reins due to envy of the wicked’s apparent success, showing honest struggle with temptation.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 73 teaches that drawing near to God and trusting the Lord is beneficial for declaring His works.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 28 concludes that drawing near to God and trusting Him enables the psalmist to declare all God’s works, emphasizing the blessing of close relationship with God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Psalms 73, whom does the psalmist desire besides God?
questions.correctAnswer: None upon earth
questions.explanation: Verse 25 states, 'Whom have I in heaven but thee? and there is none upon earth that I desire beside thee,' highlighting exclusive devotion to God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 73 encourage believers to maintain integrity and humility despite trials and feeling chastened daily?
options: By recognizing God’s discipline as loving and guiding toward glory.
By ignoring God and relying on self-strength.
By blaming others for their troubles.
By giving up on faith when trials come.
questions.correctAnswer: By recognizing God’s discipline as loving and guiding toward glory.
questions.explanation: Verses 14 and 24 explain that despite daily chastening, God’s counsel guides believers and leads them to glory, promoting perseverance with humility.

questions.question: According to Psalms 73, what is the spiritual danger of focusing on earthly prosperity of the wicked?
options: It can cause envy and near slipping of one’s spiritual steps.
It strengthens one’s faith and trust in God.
It leads to greater generosity and service.
questions.correctAnswer: It can cause envy and near slipping of one’s spiritual steps.
questions.explanation: Verses 2-3 describe the psalmist almost slipping and envying the foolish because of the wicked’s prosperity, warning against allowing envy to destabilize faith.

questions.question: How does Psalms 73 teach about God’s care for those who are faithful and clean in heart?
options: God is good to Israel and to those of a clean heart.
God only cares about power and wealth.
Faithfulness does not affect God’s attitude.
God ignores the righteous when the wicked prosper.
questions.correctAnswer: God is good to Israel and to those of a clean heart.
questions.explanation: Verse 1 affirms God’s goodness to Israel and to those with a clean heart, encouraging believers to remain pure and faithful.

questions.question: A believer feels tempted to speak arrogantly like the wicked. What does Psalms 73 warn about such speech?
options: The wicked speak loftily and arrogantly against heaven and earth, which leads to their downfall.
Arrogant speech is acceptable if it shows confidence.
Speaking loftily is a sign of God’s favor.
Speech has no impact on one’s spiritual state.
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked speak loftily and arrogantly against heaven and earth, which leads to their downfall.
questions.explanation: Verses 8-9 describe how the wicked speak corruptly and arrogantly against the heavens and earth, implying such behavior is unwise and leads to judgment.

questions.question: How does Psalms 73 encourage believers to rely on God’s counsel in daily living and decision-making?
options: God guides with counsel and will receive believers to glory.
Believers should rely solely on their own wisdom.
Counsel from God is optional and unnecessary.
God’s guidance is only for special occasions.
questions.correctAnswer: God guides with counsel and will receive believers to glory.
questions.explanation: Verse 24 teaches that God’s counsel guides believers continuously and leads to ultimate glory, highlighting the importance of seeking divine guidance.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 73 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 73.

questions.question: What reason does the psalmist give for his initial envy of the wicked in Psalms 73?
options: He saw their prosperity despite their foolishness
They had more friends than him
They were praised by the people
questions.correctAnswer: He saw their prosperity despite their foolishness
questions.explanation: In Psalms 73:3, the psalmist states he was envious of the foolish when he saw the prosperity of the wicked, highlighting a tension between apparent worldly success and moral conduct.

questions.question: According to Psalms 73:6, what metaphor describes how pride surrounds the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: As a chain
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:6 uses the metaphor of pride compassing the wicked like a chain, illustrating how pride confines and entangles them, a common Near Eastern image for bondage.

questions.question: In Psalms 73, what does the psalmist realize upon entering the sanctuary of God?
options: The ultimate fate of the wicked
The reason for his own suffering
questions.correctAnswer: The ultimate fate of the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:17 reveals that entering the sanctuary brings understanding of the wicked's end, which reflects the biblical theme that divine justice is ultimately revealed in God's presence.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Psalms 73:20 to describe the fate of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:20 uses a simile comparing the wicked's fate to a dream upon awakening, emphasizing the sudden and insubstantial nature of their downfall.

questions.question: Which Old Testament theme is reflected in Psalms 73:26 where God is described as "the strength of my heart"?
options: God as a refuge and strength in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God as a refuge and strength in times of trouble
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:26 aligns with the recurring biblical motif of God as a refuge and strength, a theme found in Psalms like 46:1 and Isaiah 40:29, emphasizing divine sustenance in human weakness.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his own state before understanding the fate of the wicked in Psalms 73:22?
options: Foolish and ignorant like a beast
questions.correctAnswer: Foolish and ignorant like a beast
questions.explanation: In Psalms 73:22, the psalmist confesses being foolish and ignorant, likening himself to a beast before God, which reflects a humbling realization in light of divine perspective.

questions.question: What is the significance of the psalmist cleansing his heart and washing his hands in Psalms 73:13?
options: It symbolizes his attempt to live innocently amidst suffering
It refers to ritual purification before sacrifice
It indicates a vow to fast and pray
It describes physical cleansing after battle
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes his attempt to live innocently amidst suffering
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:13 uses the imagery of cleansing heart and hands to express moral integrity and innocence, highlighting the psalmist’s struggle with the prosperity of the wicked despite his own righteousness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 73:25, the psalmist desires no one on earth besides God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:25 states, "Whom have I in heaven but thee? and there is none upon earth that I desire beside thee," expressing exclusive devotion to God.

questions.question: What phrase in Psalms 73:1 emphasizes God's goodness specifically to Israel?
options: Truly God is good to Israel
God is merciful to all nations
The Lord reigns over heaven and earth
Blessed are the pure in heart
questions.correctAnswer: Truly God is good to Israel
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:1 opens with the affirmation of God’s goodness to Israel, setting the context for the psalm’s meditation on divine justice and covenant relationship.

questions.question: In Psalms 73:27, what happens to those who are "far from" God?
questions.correctAnswer: They perish
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:27 states that those far from God perish, reflecting a common biblical theme of judgment against unfaithfulness and apostasy.

questions.question: What emotional response does the psalmist describe in Psalms 73:21 upon realizing the fate of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Grieved heart and pricked reins
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:21 describes the psalmist’s grief and internal turmoil upon perceiving the injustice around him, an expression of deep spiritual struggle.

questions.question: Which term from Psalms 73:9 illustrates the arrogance of the wicked in their speech?
questions.correctAnswer: "Set their mouth against the heavens"
questions.explanation: The phrase from Psalms 73:9 depicts the wicked arrogantly challenging God, a motif found in other biblical texts condemning pride (e.g., Isaiah 14:13-14).

questions.question: According to Psalms 73:23-24, how does the psalmist describe God's ongoing relationship with him?
options: Continually with me, holding my right hand and guiding me
questions.correctAnswer: Continually with me, holding my right hand and guiding me
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize God's faithful presence and guidance, a reassurance amidst the psalmist’s earlier doubts and struggles.

questions.question: What does the psalmist declare as his "portion forever" in Psalms 73:26?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:26 expresses that despite physical weakness, God is the psalmist’s eternal strength and portion, reflecting a central biblical theme of reliance on God over temporal things.

questions.question: What is the final conclusion the psalmist reaches about his relationship with God in Psalms 73:28?
options: It is good to draw near to God and trust in Him
Human wisdom is superior to divine counsel
questions.correctAnswer: It is good to draw near to God and trust in Him
questions.explanation: The psalmist concludes that close relationship and trust in God is beneficial, aligning with the wisdom literature’s encouragement to seek God’s presence for true understanding.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 73 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 73 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 73, what was the psalmist's initial emotional struggle when observing the prosperity of the wicked?
options: Envy and nearly losing his footing
questions.correctAnswer: Envy and nearly losing his footing
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:2-3 shows the psalmist's feet almost slipping and his envy of the foolish who prosper. This reflects a common human struggle with observing the wicked prospering unjustly, consistent with Job 21:7-13 and Ecclesiastes 8:14.

questions.question: What metaphor does the psalmist use to describe how pride and violence surround the wicked in Psalms 73?
questions.correctAnswer: A chain and a garment
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:6 states that pride compasseth them about as a chain, and violence covereth them as a garment, illustrating how sin entangles the wicked. This imagery parallels Proverbs 16:18 and Isaiah 59:6.

questions.question: In Psalms 73, what realization leads the psalmist to understand the ultimate fate of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Entering the sanctuary of God
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:17 reveals that the psalmist understood the wicked's end only after entering God's sanctuary, highlighting divine revelation as key to true wisdom. This is consistent with Proverbs 9:10 and Hebrews 10:19-22.

questions.question: How does Psalms 73 describe the end of the wicked?
options: Sudden destruction and utter consumption with terrors
questions.correctAnswer: Sudden destruction and utter consumption with terrors
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:19 depicts the wicked brought into desolation as in a moment, utterly consumed with terrors, emphasizing God's judgment. This aligns with Nahum 1:9 and 2 Peter 3:7.

questions.question: What does the psalmist confess about his own understanding before realizing the fate of the wicked?
options: He was foolish and ignorant, like a beast before God
questions.correctAnswer: He was foolish and ignorant, like a beast before God
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:22 describes the psalmist's former foolishness and ignorance, likening himself to a beast before God, underscoring human limitation without divine insight. This concept is related to Job 12:12 and Romans 1:21.

questions.question: What is the psalmist's declaration about God's presence and guidance despite his struggles?
options: God holds him by the right hand and guides him with counsel
questions.correctAnswer: God holds him by the right hand and guides him with counsel
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:23-24 affirm that God continually supports and guides the psalmist, reflecting God’s faithful presence even amid trials, consistent with Isaiah 41:13 and John 10:27-28.

questions.question: According to Psalms 73, what is the psalmist's ultimate desire and trust in God?
options: To draw near to God and declare His works
To escape suffering at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: To draw near to God and declare His works
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:28 expresses the psalmist’s decision to trust the Lord and proclaim God’s works, emphasizing worship and faithfulness. This echoes themes from Psalm 34:1 and Revelation 19:7.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe God’s role in his strength and portion?
options: God is the strength of his heart and his portion forever
questions.correctAnswer: God is the strength of his heart and his portion forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:26 reveals the psalmist’s conviction that God is his eternal strength and portion, aligning with Deuteronomy 33:27 and Philippians 4:13 regarding God's sustaining power.

questions.question: What question do the ungodly ask about God, as recorded in Psalms 73?
options: How does God know? Is there knowledge in the Most High?
Why does God love the righteous?
questions.correctAnswer: How does God know? Is there knowledge in the Most High?
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:11 records the scoffing of the ungodly questioning God’s knowledge, reflecting skepticism about divine justice, similar to Job 21:7 and Psalm 10:11.

questions.question: What reason does the psalmist give for feeling grieved and pricked in his reins?
options: Because of his envy and misunderstanding of the prosperity of the wicked
Because he was rejected by friends
questions.correctAnswer: Because of his envy and misunderstanding of the prosperity of the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:21-22 shows the psalmist’s heartache due to envy and ignorance about the wicked’s prosperity, highlighting the spiritual struggle with justice, paralleling Ecclesiastes 7:15 and Romans 7:15.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe the wicked’s speech and attitude toward heaven and the earth?
options: They speak loftily and set their mouth against the heavens
They whisper humbly and fear God
They pray earnestly and seek mercy
questions.correctAnswer: They speak loftily and set their mouth against the heavens
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:8-9 describes the wicked as corrupt, speaking arrogantly against God and the earth, indicative of their rebellion, comparable to Isaiah 14:13-14 and Romans 1:30.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say about those who are far from God?
options: They shall perish and are destroyed by God
They will be forgotten but live long
They will find their own way to salvation
questions.correctAnswer: They shall perish and are destroyed by God
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:27 states that those far from God perish and are destroyed, emphasizing divine judgment on unfaithfulness, consistent with Proverbs 1:28 and 2 Thessalonians 1:9.

questions.question: What does the psalmist claim about cleansing his heart and hands?
options: He has cleansed them in vain, feeling plagued all day
He has never tried to cleanse them
He is confident his purity earns him reward
questions.correctAnswer: He has cleansed them in vain, feeling plagued all day
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:13-14 express the psalmist’s frustration that his innocence seems futile as he suffers continually, reflecting Job’s complaint in Job 3:11 and Habakkuk 1:13.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say about who he desires in heaven and on earth?
options: He desires God alone in heaven and on earth
He desires many other gods besides God
He desires no one and nothing
questions.correctAnswer: He desires God alone in heaven and on earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 73:25 affirms exclusive devotion to God as the only desired one in heaven and earth, echoing Deuteronomy 6:4 and Philippians 3:8.

questions.question: How does Psalms 73 portray the relationship between God's justice and human prosperity?
options: God allows wicked prosperity temporarily before ultimate judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God allows wicked prosperity temporarily before ultimate judgment
questions.explanation: The psalmist observes wicked prosperity (verses 3-12) but understands after reflection in God's sanctuary (verse 17) that their end is destruction (verses 18-20), reflecting divine patience and final justice, consistent with Ecclesiastes 8:11 and Romans 12:19.
